official.headline: Halden Passes Away
official.anchor_line: Authorities confirm the passing of Central Oversight head Marek Halden; a brief official statement was released this morning.
official.contextual_reframing: Leadership transitions are a normal part of Stenograd’s commitment to stable, continuous governance. Our automated systems remain fully operational for all residents.

underground.headline: Halden Found Dead
underground.anchor_line: Marek Halden, architect of the city's control systems, has been found dead — no clear cause, no answers.
underground.contextual_reframing: They call it a 'normal transition,' but key systems are flickering and no one’s in charge. What happens when the man behind the BCI drops off the grid?

questions.neutral: You made it in one piece?

hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Made it. It's quieter out than you'd expect. Been busy lately, keeping up with old things. I restore mechanical typewriters. Nothing digital. Just maintenance work, really. Takes patience. Not much else to say.

In one piece, yes—longer detour than usual. I've been tending to a few typewriters at home. Keeps the mind steady. Power interruptions lately have made it difficult to finish repairs. You notice more things failing these days. Not ideal for delicate work.

I did, thanks. A bit of a walk, lots of detours after those route changes. I actually spend my evenings working on antique typewriters—restoring them, getting the old mechanisms running smooth again. Lost power halfway through a repair last night, so I’m halfway through reassembling a 1936 Adler. City’s been throwing odd little hurdles at hobbies like mine lately.

I made it, though I took the scenic route—transport’s all out of sync since that Council announcement. At least my old hobby’s survived: I restore antique typewriters, the kind that predate all this system fuss. Sometimes I log my repairs by hand, too, just to keep things tactile. Power cuts held me up last night—couldn’t finish oiling the escapement on my favorite Underwood. Strange times to trust anything that relies on electricity.

I’m here, one way or another. Things outside feel less predictable after Halden’s passing, don’t they? These days, I find comfort in my hobby: restoring and repairing antique typewriters. I started decades ago, before any compliance index or system scores mattered. I keep a handwritten log, for every machine—used to be a private pleasure, now it feels almost like rebellion. Last week, both a power cut and a missed ink delivery set me back. Makes you realize how even the simplest hobbies are caught up in the city’s troubles. Funny—those old typewriters still work, even when nothing else does.
hobby_answer: Mm. Just something to keep the hands busy.
Not much to tell—typewriters are simpler than most things in this city.
Haven’t had parts come in lately—delays everywhere, you know.
Power cuts make it harder, so I work by daylight now.
Less noise that way, which is just as well.
Yes, another one. Old habits are hard to break.
You never know what you’ll find under the keys—dust, sometimes a history.
It’s a quiet hobby, mostly safe. Or it was, before the systems started failing.
I lost a batch of ink ribbons—distribution snafus after Halden died.
Now everything’s a little slower, less reliable. Even for small things like this.
That’s right—found an Adler last week, needed some real patience.
Cleaning the springs, oiling the levers. Satisfying work—soothing, if you let it be.
Strange, though—my last order of carbon paper stalled since the network hiccups after Halden’s death.
It's odd thinking something so mechanical is affected by the systems breaking down, but here we are.
Now I keep my repairs limited to what I’ve got in stock.
Yes, spent half the afternoon aligning the platen on a 1930s Remington.
Typewriters are reliable—every function tied to something you can touch and fix, no guesswork the way things are now.
But these supply disruptions—courier missed two deliveries since the systems got jumpy after Halden.
Even ink’s become scarce. And it’s not just parts—even people seem more watchful, like I should be logging my machines in the council registry.
Doing upkeep is slower these days—so I write by hand, just as I did before all this began.
You know me too well—couldn’t sleep, so I scrubbed the type-slugs on my old Continental.
Restoring these machines is like preserving little pockets of order. Simple mechanics—no hidden motives. It’s a comfort, especially compared to Council routines.
Halden’s death threw everything off. Pension delayed, shipments lost. Had to scrounge old ribbon from a neighbor just to finish a paragraph last night.
Tried logging entries in my paper journal, but now even that makes me wary. You never know who’s watching for manual records, especially with the network down.
Honestly, doing this work used to make me feel invisible. Now, every keystroke sounds too loud. But stopping would be the real betrayal—to myself, and to how the world ought to work.

main.opener: You ever feel like the air's just... heavier now?
variants: Always feels heavier when things don’t work right.
The transport’s late. Pension too.
Systems used to run clean—now, not even a clerk can confirm who I am.
Can’t say I like standing in lines these days.
People I don’t recognize taking more interest—just a feeling, really.
Feels like you’re waiting for something that never comes.
Used to be you knew what to expect, day or night.
Lately, the buses stop whenever they want. My pension’s delayed—they say ‘system error’.
Waited over an hour today, just to be told my paperwork wasn’t showing up.
Noticed some new faces hanging around my building; maybe I’m imagining things, but I double-check the locks, you know?
There’s something about these days… can’t shake it off.
I suppose I feel it too. Ever since they made the announcement about Halden.
Half the city’s stuck in queues—my pension’s held up, everyone in limbo.
Was at the admin center for hours; clerk said the system couldn’t even find my record.
It’s not just me—saw some odd types watching our block tonight, never seen them before.
Feels like we’re all just waiting for the gears to turn again, but nobody knows who’s got the wrench anymore.
You could say the air’s heavy—you feel like someone’s turned down the volume on the city, but you’re still listening for something.
After Halden passed, the routines I counted on just fell apart. Pension’s not coming, trams don’t follow the map, even my ID isn’t showing up some places.
Administrative office, packed with people today—everyone restless, clerk blinking at a dead terminal.
I saw these men hanging by my building; no uniforms, but they had that look—counting steps, reading faces, probably not from here.
Sometimes I move things around the apartment, just in case. Feels like I’m trying to stay unnoticed in a world where everything is noticed.
I haven’t slept right in a week. Feels like the city is holding its breath.
It’s not just heavier—it’s different. You remember how this place ran: not always fair, but at least the routine meant something.

I spent half my life ensuring things ran on time, making sure the Council’s machinery didn’t hiccup. Now, my pension’s delayed, I can’t get a straight answer from a single office, and my name’s floating somewhere in the void.
Today I stood in line like a ghost—clerk couldn’t even pull up my status, just shrugged and told me to check back. That never used to happen, not with the systems Halden built.
There were strangers tonight outside my block, lingering too long. I recognized the way they watched—like the old days, when someone was about to disappear. I moved my papers, locked doors twice.

Funny, for all the systems, there’s no one left to ask. I still carry the briefcase from my last year—everyone whispers about what’s inside. Truth is, I keep it close because it’s the only thing that feels real anymore.
I thought I understood the rules here, but now all I feel is… lost, to be honest. Like the world I worked for is turning into fog.
main.emotion: Worn out, unsettled, quietly searching for reassurance.

emotional.opener: Nikola, no matter how things shift out there, people still remember what matters—and so do I. You're not alone in this.
variants: Yes, well, I suppose that's reassuring to hear.
Some things are best left unsaid, still.
Thank you. Words like that are rare these days.
I try not to forget what really counts, even when it's not so clear.
That's kind of you, Alex. It helps to know someone sees past the surface.
Sometimes you wonder if memory is the only thing that carries you forward.
I appreciate the reminder.
It means more than you know, Alex. Too easy to feel invisible, these days.
I've spent most of my life trying to fade into the background, for better or worse.
Sometimes, a simple word does more than these systems ever could.
It's funny—there are moments I almost feel myself again, listening to you.
I appreciate that, truly. I've spent years making sure I wasn't noticed—always a supporting part, never the one on stage.
Things used to feel structured, if a bit impersonal, but at least predictable.
Now I find myself reaching for old habits, just to feel steady.
You remind me, in small ways, that connection survives the rest of it.
Even after all this, recognition from someone genuine means something real.
Thank you, Alex. That steadiness is worth far more than you probably realize.

factual.opener: Something happened, didn’t it? Cut the vagueness—just say what you know.
variants: They made it official—Halden’s dead. That’s what they said, anyway.
No cause mentioned.
Systems started failing right after.
Those are the facts they gave the public.
Doesn’t sit right, but that’s all they let slip.
Announcement came down—Halden gone, no reason given.
He was found in his own place, I heard that much.
Systems went haywire after—public saw it, lines everywhere.
Council’s kept quiet, no replacement named yet.
The timing of those failures… makes you wonder, but that’s as much as I know.
Halden was found dead—right after missing a scheduled audit, if you look at the timeline.
They said cardiac arrest, but nobody’s shown a proper report.
Automated systems locked up almost the same hour—admin couldn’t function for a bit.
Council just released a bare bones statement, kept it impersonal.
You’d think with all those controls, someone would step in, but it’s all fallback mode now.
Halden’s death didn’t look natural—a sealed room, no explanation, just a hint in the official line.
He had special access; systems started to fail without him managing the credentials.
On the inside, medical reports were sealed, something about ‘sedative traces’—not public knowledge.
No interim leader, no chain of command—everything stalling, factions quiet in public, loud in private.
Even the Council’s routines are off. Councilors are maneuvering, but you won’t see that in the news.
I saw the logs myself—last entry showed Halden going in, nothing after eleven at night.
Medical report sealed quick—Council’s health unit, not even usual protocol. Sedatives, not just heart failure.
The same cycle—Council split the minute Halden was gone. Directorate types more visible around admin towers now.
So many flagged names just vanished from watchlists before this, rules inconsistent—nobody’s talking about it.
I spent years shepherding the Council’s diaries. Quiet disputes, performance scores, all that—now, it’s like the algorithm’s unanchored and the old guard act like it’s business as usual.
The security office is rerouting data requests. Even with my clearance, you can hardly get at what matters. Only thing that’s certain—they’re more worried than they let on.

dilemma.opener: Looks like you've got more on your plate than that drink.
variants: Long night. Strange faces around, that’s all.
Things are shifting, people wanting answers.
Old rules don’t cover every mess, do they?
It’s just a matter of keeping things balanced.
Some folks are knocking where they shouldn't be.
I’ve got something certain people suddenly want—never sits well.
Not every choice fixes the bigger problem.
Every move draws eyes; I’m watching my step.
Council runners have started appearing at odd hours—they’re after something I’ve kept locked away for years.
City’s slipping, too many hands reaching for the same lever now.
I can let one group smooth things over behind curtains, or toss the key into the middle and let them wrestle for it.
Either way, quiet suffering continues, just with new faces at the door.
You find out where people stand by what they ask you to risk.
Tonight, messages came from every camp—none subtle, all urgent.
I still hold the path to stabilizing this mess, and they know it.
If I pass everything to the old calm, we go back to tidy halls, but everyone outside just keeps stumbling in the dark.
If I let it out to every hand, some might use it well, some might not, but the game finally moves into the daylight.
Alex, I see the tally of mistakes is never public, only the bill at the end.
Hard to recall who benefits when all you do is keep the system running.
Alex, you ever feel the ground shift and realize you’re standing where everyone’s aiming their next step?
Every Council side sent their own, like the old days when only whispers mattered, but this time, they want more than silence—they need the keys I used to carry.
If I give it all to the ones promising peace, nothing changes for folks like us—quiet on the surface, pain under the skin, questions left to die in locked offices.
If I split it across their hands, I risk open conflict, system falters, blame spreads, and maybe—just maybe—someone new gets to speak, if they can stand the noise.
Both roads taste of loyalty and betrayal, just to different ghosts.
I remember the first time Halden asked me to hold back what I knew—said order needs silence. But I’m tired of acting like the only cost is paperwork.
Thing is, I know whatever I do, someone pays in full—and this time, I’ll see every line when the reckoning comes.

belief_a.belief: Order is safer for the people than open conflict.
monologue: If we let things spiral, it won't just be administrators at risk—everyone pays the price.
I watched quiet order keep the city standing when tempers flared before; chaos has never protected us, just bled us dry.
People don't want a spectacle, they want doors that open and power that stays on.
When the system holds steady, most slip by unnoticed—better than open fear.
I know what happens when the city starts to fracture. The last time, it took years to feel normal again.
It's not a perfect peace, but I'm not sure we're built for storms anymore.
supportive_response: Order really did keep things from falling apart, you’re right.
Most folks would rather not see the sausage made—just that it’s on the table.
That’s a way of seeing things, Nikola. What else weighs on you tonight?
challenging_response: Order may look safe, but silence lets rot spread out of sight.
Sometimes the cracks need to show before healing can start—calm isn’t always clean.
If that’s how you see it, what pushes you toward the path you’re on now?

belief_a.belief: The Harmonists, though flawed, value stability over ambition or control.
monologue: The Harmonists, for all their faults, don't set out to break things—they want things to last.
I've watched them—cautious by nature, slow to move, never hunting for power like the others.
Maybe they're conservative, even dull, but ambition burns hotter elsewhere, and much brighter.
Their idea of risk is to patch quietly, not stir up dust. Sometimes that's the best you can ask for.
If I hand them the reins, at least they won't pull the city apart just to see who gets what.
I’m not blind to their worries, but the alternative is letting more reckless hands steer.
supportive_response: You’re right, the Harmonists rarely chase glory—they just want the city standing.
Sometimes dull is what saves us from burning out entirely.
What else drives your thinking tonight, Nikola?
challenging_response: Stability can be a cover for staying in power—maybe that’s their ambition.
Even letting things stay the same can harm us more than change might.
I see your reasoning, but what’s the next principle you’re weighing?

belief_a.belief: The city cannot survive a public breakdown—secrecy is a lesser evil.
monologue: If the whole system falters in the open, it’s not just the factions who suffer—the city’s heart stops beating.
People panic when they see what truly holds them up, and panic is harder to fix than any broken code.
There’s always been a curtain between the machinery and the street. Pulling it back could do more harm than letting things stay hidden.
I don’t trust secrecy, but I trust fear even less. Open collapse is a door you can’t easily close.
Mistakes get buried this way, I know. But maybe, sometimes, not every truth needs to breathe.
The lesser evil is still evil, but I’ve seen what the greater one can do here.
supportive_response: You’re not wrong—panic spreads faster than any code error ever could.
Sometimes what people don’t know really is what keeps them calm.
Let’s keep thinking through each piece, Nikola. What else shapes this decision for you?
challenging_response: Secrecy has a cost—you know that better than most, Nikola.
Trust might be stronger than you imagine, if people get a chance to learn.
I hear you, but what other reasons are keeping you leaning this way?

belief_b.belief: Transparency, even chaos, is better than another generation of hidden control.
monologue: We’ve spent too many years sweeping problems under data layers.
Whenever we made things neat, someone always paid the price in silence.
If I pass the codes to everyone, it will be messy—maybe even ugly for a while.
But at least people will see what’s actually running this city.
Maybe then the real rot finally has a light on it.
Hard to say if Stenograd could ever handle open truth, but we’ve never tried.
supportive_response: I hear you—hidden truths just rot from within.
The city’s long lived in managed shadows; some sunlight might do more good than harm.
Speaking of honesty, what else is weighing on you tonight?
challenging_response: That’s bold, but chaos has a heavy cost, Nikola.
Sometimes a little order stops things from breaking beyond repair—secrets can be a shield too.
If you’re still undecided, what else is pushing you toward this risk?

belief_b.belief: No single group should be handed the citys fate in secret.
monologue: The Council always said unity, but they meant control—by the smallest, safest hands.
Granting one bloc the keys is just old history, wrapped in new names.
I’ve watched how quickly they shut doors once they have what they want.
If I share with all, at least no one can dictate the outcome in a back room.
Perhaps this way, the city chooses, not the few behind frosted glass.
Funny—the only fair deal here might be no deal at all.
supportive_response: That’s fair—letting one circle decide for all never changes anything.
Some things only breathe in shared air. Maybe this is how you break the pattern.
Go on, Nikola; you sound like someone with more on their chest tonight.
challenging_response: True, but without a steady hand, things can shatter fast.
Sometimes you need someone decisive, even if it’s far from ideal.
Care to tell me what else is driving this thinking for you?

belief_b.belief: Shaking the system may force real change, even if it means a difficult transition.
monologue: Every ‘smooth restoration’ just locks us into the same cycles, paper over paper.
A little upheaval might be the only way—systems ossify when left unchallenged.
Breaking things openly might frighten people, but stagnation is worse long-term.
If I do nothing, I’m just one more piece keeping the gears grinding quietly on.
Risking a shake-up means living with broken pieces for a while—but maybe what remains is worth it.
Never has progress come in silence here—maybe it’s time it echoed a bit.
supportive_response: Sounds like you want real movement, not just fresh paint over the cracks.
Trouble doesn’t last forever, but stagnation might.
If there’s more you’re weighing up, now’s as good a time as any to let it out.
challenging_response: Upheaval brings casualties, Nikola—that’s always the first lesson.
Sometimes the safest hands are the steadiest, even in boredom.
But tell me, is there something deeper behind all this unrest in you?

monologue_a: Order has its merits, always did.
Some things must go quietly, that's all.
Sometimes, the old paths are safest.
Best not to stir what can be settled in silence.
I’ve chosen what keeps things moving.
You reminded me, stability weighs more than noise.
I had to give the right people what only I recall.
Things run smoother without open hands in the gears.
You've pointed me back to quiet solutions, Alex.
This sort of thing, better done quietly.
You helped me see, Alex—quiet restoration is needed now.
I’m trusting the familiar hands to put things straight.
You warned me about the cost of chaos. I listened.
It’s best those who kept the city running keep fixing it, unseen.
Your perspective pushed me to preserve order, even if the city forgets.
Alex, your words reminded me why calm matters in a storm.
I’ve handed what I know to the old keepers—no fanfare, no spectacle.
Your stories at the bar about BCI’s edge, they stuck with me tonight.
Hard choices leave residue, but you tipped the scales toward continuity over exposure.
I can’t invite chaos in—so the restoration passes quietly, thanks to you.
Tonight’s city feels like a different world, Alex, but you brought me back to why people need the illusion of calm.
You spoke of growing up in chaos, what quiet order gave to your family—I remember that too.
I’ve given everything to the ones who patch things silently. Let them hide the cracks, for now.
Maybe it’s cowardice, maybe just age; but your reminders about the cost of public panic—those mattered most here.
I trust the old hands. And now, because of your honesty, I’ve chosen not to force this city to see itself raw. That’s closure, in its way.
monologue_b: Sometimes all doors open at once, that's life.
Hands off, let others find what they will.
No hiding now, whatever comes comes.
If things scatter, so be it.
I've decided: let the chips fall.
You made me see, secrets only last so long.
I left out the whole truth—let them run after it now.
Spilling what I know to everyone evens the field, for better or worse.
Unrest is already here, Alex—let them struggle in the daylight.
Some things can't stay hidden, and you reminded me why.
Alex, your questions pushed me—I released pieces to every side at once.
It’s risk, but maybe competition brings clarity.
You often say the city needs daylight—now they’ll have it, even if it pains us.
Exposing the workings, even half-hidden, breaks the old grip.
I suppose the struggle’s out in the open now—because holding it back never sits well for long.
You made me remember that shutting doors breeds resentment, Alex.
Tonight I sent what I know in fragments—each faction gets a chance, but not the full key.
It’ll be messy; you didn’t shy from saying as much. We’ve hidden too long.
Maybe disorder is its own kind of honesty. I’m grateful you didn’t let me settle for “normal.”
This city runs on secrets, but you showed me the human debt that stacks up unseen. Now, they all have to answer to it.
I remember your voice, Alex—how you said silence feeds the city’s shadow. That lingers.
Tonight I put the pieces in many hands, knowing chaos might break through but so might something new.
You said nobody chooses to distrust the system, they’re forced to. I can’t prop that up any longer.
It’s dangerous, I know—but confrontation clears rot faster than quiet rot. You made me face that.
Whatever storm comes now, I walk into it clear, because someone—I think you—believes we still owe the city its truth, not just its quiet.
monologue_self: Old habits die hard. I made my move.
Doesn’t matter much who watches now.
Keep walking, that’s what matters.
I did what was needed, no more to say.
Paths bend, but I keep to mine.
I weighed it, and made my own way—habit, I suppose.
Advice is advice, but choices are private.
My decision is set. Practicality wins.
Been through worse—this follows the same pattern.
I’ll sort it. I always have.
Alex, your words spun around but didn’t quite land for me. I’ve chosen the quieter path.
Sometimes the bar doesn’t give answers, just echoes; I’ll leave it in the old circuit’s hands.
Your view mattered, but the decision had its own gravity—order returns how it must.
Maybe it’s cowardice, maybe discipline, but I can’t court disorder.
Whatever comes, I’ll stand by what I know: secrets best kept quiet, for now.
Didn’t find the answer at the bar tonight, Alex. Guess old instincts took over in the end.
I know you meant to help, but in the quiet I followed what’s always kept the city breathing: a silent pass to the caretakers.
Your reminders of what we owe people weigh heavy, but fear of chaos still tips my hand.
In a city of watchers, being watched steers the hand tighter. I went with what I remember working, even if it costs something else.
You tried, truly, but my track is laid, and I followed it anyway.
Alex, sometimes you offer the right questions, but tonight I heard ghosts louder: choices made in darker years, order bought at a price.
You pressed for openness; I shut the door. Some habits come from wounds.
The city’s patterns—quiet repair, silent hands—still have my loyalty, even if it’s a failing.
I know it may not be right, but I can’t betray what built this order, not while I hold the last piece.
You gave me honesty; I still walked back into the old ways. Maybe next time, the bar offers more than memories.

hobby.message: Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, holding up. Just a long day. I usually unwind by making a few paper models when I get home. Haven’t really had much time this week, though.
It’s… alright. I do a bit of origami after work—helps with stress. Lately, work’s gotten complicated and I keep getting interrupted. Hard to focus on folding with everything going on.

Mm, as much as anyone, I guess. Most nights I fold origami—complex stuff, not just cranes. It keeps my mind busy. But the last few nights, after all the system issues at work, I couldn’t fold a thing right. Even my usual models came out wrong.

Honestly, not great. I’ve been trying to relax by folding those advanced origami tessellations out of old report paper. It usually shuts out everything else. But with these weird system delays since Halden died, even origami’s felt pointless. My hands just wouldn’t do what I wanted—like they’re waiting for something to break.

No, not really—thanks for asking. I do origami to manage my thoughts, the really tough modular stuff, hundreds of folds per piece. It’s something I picked up years ago, when everything first started to feel automated. But after Halden… and how the whole BCI stutters now, even at home, I can’t focus on patterns or symmetry. I spent hours last night shredding scrap paper, folding and re-folding, just watching everything fall apart—like the city can’t hold its shape, and I can’t either.
hobby_answer: Yeah, a few cranes. Nothing complicated lately.
Been short on time. System issues at work.
Paper's not the best these days.
I mostly just stick to basic folds now.
Things have been... off since Halden—anyway, not much to say.
Made some cranes last night, actually.
Hard to focus with everything changing at the Directorate.
Recent system failures mean more overtime for me.
I use old work forms for folding—plenty of those piling up.
Finished pieces keep coming out uneven. Maybe it's just the stress.
Yeah, I folded some cranes—it's what I do to clear my head after work.
I like using old report paper; the stiffness gives nice sharp lines.
Except lately, it's harder to unwind. Lots of system delays since Halden passed.
I brought home extra scraps after those data reviews went wrong—thought folding might help.

I did—cranes, spirals, even tried a complex tessellation. It's my one quiet habit after a noisy day.
There's something calming about methodical folds. I use anything: old updates, obsolete forms.
Only now, with the Directorate scrambling after Halden, there’s this constant tension. You feel it everywhere.
Yesterday, I caught myself folding the same design three times and still couldn't get it right—my mind was stuck on all the missing profile data.
Even origami feels different when the whole system’s out of sync. It’s like forgetting steps to something you’ve done forever.
Yeah, cranes, but they’re not coming out right. Normally folding lets me sort through the day—a mental reset. I started doing it when I moved here, just to have something quiet and concrete.

I’ve got a stack of failed attempts at home—mostly folded accident reports from last week, after we lost that whole set of flagged profiles. Strange, how the city’s so organized on paper but actual paper feels harder to work with lately.
After Halden died, I noticed even handling paper made me jittery. The system is always there, even in the margins—delays at work, random people dropped from lists, no answers from the top.
Usually I can block it out with origami. Lately, I finish a model and all I see is the shape of the gaps—the things that slipped through. Kind of ironic, I guess.
Never thought stress from system failures would follow me all the way home, but now even my hobby’s tangled with it. Just… funny, in a way.

main.opener: That makes me think - what's been different for you lately?
variants: Not much, just the usual routines.
Some things have slowed down at work, that's all.
A few system updates lagging—nothing too unusual.
My schedule's shifted a bit, so I'm around here more often.
Honestly, it's just one of those weeks.
Work's gotten... slower, if that makes sense.
Some of the alerts I usually check aren't coming through the way they should.
I've had to spend longer at my desk, double-checking things manually.
I guess it's thrown off my evenings a bit; I've skipped my usual stop here just to keep up.
Feels like something's out of place, but I can't quite put my finger on it.
Things changed after Halden—our director—died last week.
My access at work suddenly got limited, without warning.
The automated systems that used to handle my reports are missing updates, so I'm stuck reviewing everything by hand.
Profiles on my lists are disappearing or getting cleared, and nobody explains why.
I've been staying late trying to make sense of it, and it’s starting to get to me.
Ever since Halden was found dead, the systems we rely on…they haven’t felt right.
I was used to knowing what was happening—now, alerts are missing, and I’m losing access to basic tools I need.
There are profiles on our watchlists that are just gone, no record of what happened.
